This was a short (20-30 minute) visual novel that did a great job of poking fun at the video game industry while also poking fun at itself. The protagonist is an aspiring, struggling calligrapher who has to make ends meet working a crappy job so she can pay for her crappy apartment so she can try to find success as a calligrapher. However, she realizes that she had been so focused on success that she lost sight of her passion for her art. Calligraphy, and the story itself, is obviously a metaphor for what this game developer has gone through, but I thought it was well written with nice artwork and an appropriate sense of self deprecation. Plus, I laughed out loud at the ending. It was truly hilarious in the context of the story.

Very well done, free to play title, and one I definitely recommend trying out. You wont regret your time spent with this game.

This VN was an exquisite read. I'll be honest by saying that I only tried this VN on a whim.

The story is about a young woman named Vinty who is trying to establish herself as a proclaimed calligrapher.

Pros:

-Story: As you read through, you personally will be able to relate to her sorrow, her anger, general misfortunes, and happiness if you've been in the same shoes as her. You can really feel the emotion and soul that the writer put into creating this story; I'll safely say that Vinty is a representation of the writer themself. Due to risk of spoilers I won't tread futher.
-Visuals: The visuals are colorful and cheerful throughout the VN, putting a light mood even on moments that would normally not be happy. Good for the story that this VN is.

Cons:

-Choices: Well, it can be, or it can be a Pro depending on how you view it. In the VN, you have to make choices and the choices are either correct or game over. Getting game over screens were an interuption on the immersion experience (to me), but as a general rule of thumb you just gotta be the well-natured person that Vinty is and you'll do fine.
-Abrupt Ending: The other being that when I was approaching the ending, I was laughing with abandon at what was going on in the story, and then it ended. Just like that. But I hear a sequel is in the making so that more than makes up for it.

TL;DR

The feels I have for this VN are the same that Vinty had for her video game (P.S. it was a good feeling). If you read this VN you'll know what I mean, and you will likely have the same feels. And yeah, this review took longer to write than it took to read this VN, but for 10 minutes of your time, why not peel your eyes away from those trashy celebrity shows and give this free gem a go?

reviewText:
Like I've been trying to tell everyone for years, it's not the size that matters, it's what you do with it that counts!

Without Within is a very short, free, visual novel about a young woman called Vinty who dreams of being the world's greatest calligrapher whilst trying to get by in her day to day life and not totally suck at it, too. Yeeaaahhh... world's greatest calligrapher...

OK. Sure. Why not?

You'll follow her and her innermost thoughts over a couple of days as she tries to sell her works, hold down an unfulfilling job and deal with her crotchety, old landlady to boot. Oh, and depending on the choice you make, also prevent a small boy from being bummed to death. I like the way the game gives you choices at a handful of points throughout, making the right one will eventually deliver you to the final, good ending, while making the wrong choice will result in something bad happening and end the game. It adds a little something extra to what could easily be a very linear experience, being a visual novel. Or at least that's what I've found with what's admittedly so far been a very brief flirtation with the genre. Though games like this make me want to try more.

The art style is kinda minimal but still pleasing, and the character design beyond adorable (I especially love her eyes which appear to be two thick lines made of brush strokes. A really nice touch to the character). Vinty could probably have come across as a little entitled or maybe even a tad petulant were she not so lovable, thanks in no small part to the clever and astute writing. I guess these games largely live or die based on the quality of the writing (at least if it's not relying on drawings of boobs and weird squealing audio, as this one isn't), and this game most definitely blossoms from it. It's self-aware and referential without beating the player/reader over the head with it, and is funny and interesting enough to keep them engaged 'til the end, which will only be about 15 or 20 minutes, even seeing all the endings.

So if you have some time to spare and want to have a brief, pleasant read of something cute and whimsical, then it's well worth giving this freebie a shot. Even though it's only the story of a small time chaligrapher, you brush off this stroke of inkredible genius at your own peril.

reviewText:
Since this was free, I was not expecting much. But then I remembered all the doujin novels I read over the past few months and decided to give this game a chance.

I got the best ending on my first try. Even after getting all the bad endings, the game took me only twenty minutes to beat. Unlike all the other doujin visual novels I've played, nothing was unlocked after I beat it, which was quite disheartening.

Still, I like the art, and the music is okay. But the best part about this game was the message. It's a message that I feel applies to the whole concept of doujin novels as a whole: It's never about the presentation or story length, it's about having the passion and heart to get a message across. And that is why I recommend this novel, because I did not like doujin novels for their production values or story length. I liked them because they had a charm to them that most triple-A titles lack.

Way to go, InvertMouse.

reviewText:
Much like how Vinty was ready to cast judgment on Sunflower War, I was ready to cast judgment on Without Within.  Visual Novels and RPGs usually require commitment and the lack of achievements usually leads to a lack of incentive on my end.  Of course, after hearing it's short, I decided to boot it up.  This ended up being a repeat of the Port of Call experience to prove me wrong.  HOORAY!!!!  :D

This is a short game with multiple endings.  Choose the right path and the story continues, choose the wrong path and the story ends immediately and hillariously (well, all save for 1 or 2).  The comedy's rich and the protagonist is enjoyable and relatable.  To be honest, I kinda' see myself in her.  She kinda' makes me want to get back into drawing and writing again...did Vinty teach me a valuable lesson?  Hmm....

If time is a concern, the main story is about 15-20 minutes long (about half of a 30 minute cartoon).  If you're a slow reader, it may take you up to 30 minutes.

The musical score is fitting and pleasant to listen to, the artwork is like a breath of fresh air, and the story is a welcome sight.  I smiled and had a warm feeling inside after reading this short story.  My hat's off to you, Invertmouse.  Bravo!!!


From a critical standpoint, I'm thinking of where some flaws lie....I'm tempted to find some sort of flaws or room for improvement.  Where are the flaws?  WHERE ARE THE FLAWS?!  Maybe a lack of a gallery...or maybe achievements?  Wait...it's fine without achievements!!!   ....Arrrrrgh!  I want to 9/10.   Nnnngh.... Oh forget it!!!  This jewel deserves the full praise!!!!!!

10/10  A short experience you're missing out on if you haven't looked into this hidden gem yet!!!

Steam's formatting is pretty awful..
....
Without Within is a short but charming novel brought to us by InvertMouse, a name I had previously not heard but that I will not soon forget. It features soft, well-drawn artwork, a great soundtrack, and a lovable main character that leaves you wanting more. Despite the minimal playtime, I found Without Without thoroughly enjoyable and encourage any visual novel lover to give it a chance.
....
The story follows Vinty, a down-on-her-luck girl trying to become a calligraphy artist. During her journey she’s met nothing but adversity and the story is just a segment of her life as she attempts to conquer her own feelings of hopelessness.
.....
The main menu was the first bit of brilliance that I ran into. The artwork is adorable, the opening theme is soothing, and the interface is very simple and easy to use.  Within only a few seconds of loading the game the novel had grabbed my attention and positioned itself as “not your average indie VN” in my head. The only issue I found with the menu and interface was the stark contrast of the button click soundbyte and calm background music. It was too sharp and loud; a softer sound effect would have fit much better.
....
As I loaded into the game the soundtrack grabbed my attention for a second time, leading me nicely into some simple, yet cute, artwork and starting off the story in a rather amusing fashion. Throughout the entire novel, the soundtrack never disappoints and always fits the mood of each scene perfectly.
....
The soundtrack wasn’t the only thing that made the atmosphere of Without Within, however. The art style was soft, simple, and cute and really lent itself to the story in a way that most generic visual novels don’t often do. When you combine art with music, the result is a wonderful atmosphere that does a great job amplifying the simplicity of the story.
.....
Speaking of the story, the only word I can really use to describe this one is charming. It has a few funny moments, a sad moment here and there, and some great bits that really dig their way into your brain and just make you feel good. I found myself involuntarily smiling many times throughout my first playthrough, connecting with the main character and her melancholy life on a personal level.
.....
InvertMouse really outdid themselves on Without Within, and despite my negative predisposition going into the story, I couldn’t help but love every bit of it. The simple artwork, fitting soundtrack, and heartwarming plot all came together to create a beautiful work of art. I highly encourage anyone who enjoys Visual Novels to give Without Within a chance, because it’s not your average indie novel.

reviewText:
Hello to all and the dev! (I know you'll read this eventually since you seem to be following fan feedback very closely from what I've seen :D)

So I saw this game on the Steam front page and I figured Well hey! It's a free game and judging from the reviews it doesn't take that long to complete!" So I installed and played it.

Is it absolutely amazing? Eh I wouldn't say so. Did I feel that it was worth my time? 100% so and maybe even more than that!

When I walked away from Without Within I felt not the amount of immense triumph and satisfaction that I get from the best games ever made but instead a small warm feeling at the pit of my heart.

I am currently a Master's student in Taiwan (So yes I speak Chinese :D) who is pursuing a degree in digital software
date:
and gaming in general so I have felt more or less the experiences a creative person goes through. It is not uncommon to lose sight that you do what you do simply because you love it. It's unfortunate but it happens.

After playing Without Within though I experienced a nice slice of a relatable experience through Vinty's short little journey. Despite the fact that being supported is every artist's dream one should not forget the reason that you started off: Because you love it. Vinty lost her way for a moment and I'm happy to see that she found it back.

When you love what you do it will show in your work and that will be what gives it its soul.

If I want to be a bit critical I would say that the biggest current problem may be in the pacing of the story. The story tends to jump around an awful lot and scenes don't seem to pan out properly before they go on into the next one. Also many of the endings seem to cause the game to end very abruptly which just leaves me sitting there baffled at what had just transpired. It's seemingly a small problem but one that bogs down the experience from being a much better one. It can be easy to lose sight of pacing as an author of a work so lots and lots of beta testing will definitely help one stamp out errors such as these in the final release!

Even with that being said though I liked the 10 minutes that I spent with this game. So...thank you InvertMouse. Thank you for this short and relatable experience. I wish you the very best of luck in your future endeavors! :D

I will be sure to tell my friends about this game and tell them to go check it out for a nice little 10 minutes!

And for all my fellow gamers who happen to be reading this....the game is free! Go play it and have a nice little 10 minutes :D"

reviewText:
A Paladin's Steam Review: Without Within. Short Yet Personable AVN.Genre: Anime Visual Novel
Developed & Published by: InvertMouse
Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux.
Business Model: Free.
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
This game is really short. I finished it in 20mins. When you finish a game that quickly, what is there to really to talk about? Well, other than it being an anime visual novel following a weekend in the life of a creator. No, it's not the most exciting or interesting concept you've ever been presented with. The game was originally created for the fans of the artist's original works and I came in not knowing anything about the creator or her work.

PC Settings
Included settings are basic with windowed/fullscreen mode, text reading speeds & language options. It runs, it doesn't crash and I didn't have any bugs crop up either. But with a game this short, I would certainly hope not. It's not too bad.

Final Thoughts
Its a day in the life of a struggling creator. I will admit that it does speak to me because I’m in a very similar boat. Is it worth playing? I'm 50/50 on it but as this is free, well, hard to say no. I think it's worth playing if you're a content creator or struggling artist because I think you'll sympathize with what the character is going through. I did take a look at the bad" endings (I finished the game in one go on the good endings. It's not hard to figure out which choices are "right" and "wrong"). The bad choices were rather humorous if slightly exaggerated.

reviewText:
Without Within is a cute, but rather short Visual Novel both Developed and Published by InvertMouse. The game clocks in to be around 15 minutes to an hour-ish depending on the choices you make in the game. I happened to choose all the correct choices my first playthrough resulting in a 15 minute completion time, but the game was very well made and very stylized despite its length.

Without Within's story is very relatable and contains a few morals that anyone can value. The dialogue was funny, cute, and well written with a few choices here and there that can ultimately bring you down a different story path. The soundtrack and sound effects were nicely composed and blended well with the scenes, thus adding more life into the story. The art and animation is, hands down, one of the strongest features of the game. The art is reminiscent of many animes (Lucky Star comes to mind) and the animation helps to liven up the scenes a bit so that they aren't too static.

The developer has confirmed that they are working on a sequel to Without Within and I am definitely looking forward to learning more of Vinty's story.

In conclusion, I would definitely recommend Without Within to anyone since it is short and not too heavy on the reading. It provided me with a cute story in 15 or so minutes and I couldn't ask for anything more especially since it was free! Everyone should definitely check it out!

reviewText:
Well, what can I say - this game disappointed me. I was very interested in it from the time it was released, (come on, visual novel in steam, and it's free!)  but after playing I feel like I wasted my time.
Graphics
What could I say about graphics? It's not brilliant, but despite very simplistic manner, it's  nice and appealing. At least I like the style of the artist. But you know what? It's not good enough to recommend this game. It's not the game you would like to play because of sight seeing. Also, the game is quite short (read below about it), and if you've seen screenshots on the store page - you've seen about a half of game. Disappointing, huh?
Music
Well, there is music. It's not bad, but I wouldn't listen it outside the game. When I was distracted from the game for a while, my wife asked me to turn off the sound, because she was annoyed of listening for it too long. Definitely, that music can't be a reason to play this game.
Plot
And now, the worst part. The plot. It's short. As you can see, I have 2.5 hours in game, and as I said - I was distracted for a while, leaving game open. So, real time to explore all the choices in game, reading all text thoughtfully should be less then half an hour. Did I say choices? I lied, if you chose wrong answer - the game just give you a bad end almost instantly, so actually there isn't any routes, it's linear. Deep meaning? Well, ideas in game are good, but all simple and plain, so it actually don't made me think about it a lot. Nice characters? Oh, sorry for the plural form, I should have said character. Nope again, protagonist is simple and not interesting, not the one you would sympathize. I wonder, how much time author of a plot spent on writing it. One hour? Two? Ten minutes? We'll never know.
Summary
Nothing to see here. I've read this game to be sure if I should buy the second part, but now I'm sure I should not. The game didn't touched me even a little. I would like a deep game with meaning, I would like a stupid game with boobs, I would like a funny game with good humor, but this game is not one of those. Waste of my time (and waste of game artist's time too, sadly).

reviewText:
Without Within is a very short independent Visual Novel that was developed by InvertMouse with art by Karousel.  The story revolves around our main character, Vinty, and her struggle to make ends meet while following her dreams of being  a professional calligrapher.

From a technical standpoint Without Within does just fine.   It runs off Ren'Py so all the normal quirks associated with the engine are present.  Font is easy to read and everything functions as expected.  The music is well done, though often understated and lilting, it does fit the various scenes well.  As for art, Karousel did a fantastic job and more thought went into the design than the average reader will initially expect.  More on that latter.

The actual journey that we take with Vinty, whether she is dreaming of stardom or fending off the soul crushing nature of actual reality, is short but sweet.  Clocking at under 20 minutes to explore all of the paths (which function in a Bad End versus a continuation of the story system), Without Within can be immensely charming, funny, sweet, a bit too real at times for those of us that did a stint as a starving artist.  The story is a love letter to creative types but something everyone can relate to: It isn't easy to blaze your own trail but if it was would the journey actually be worth it?

So, is Without Within worth your time?  Absolutely!  It is a cute little tale that is short but full of character.  Is Without Within worth your money?  That is a difficult question to answer and one I leave up to the reader after they finish the story.  If you enjoyed it, as I did, I personally suggest spending the meager amount to show your support and unlock some goodies.  The Art Book in particular is very interesting as they discuss some of the design decisions for the game and you get an interesting inside look at how a small team would go about putting together a project like this.

But if you find Visual Novels even the least bit appealing, there is literally no reason to not spend a bit of time to go through this one.

Score: 7/10

reviewText:
Without Within is a very short independent Visual Novel that was developed by InvertMouse with art by Karousel.  The story revolves around our main character, Vinty, and her struggle to make ends meet while following her dreams of being  a professional calligrapher.

From a technical standpoint Without Within does just fine.   It runs off Ren'Py so all the normal quirks associated with the engine are present.  Font is easy to read and everything functions as expected.  The music is well done, though often understated and lilting, it does fit the various scenes well.  As for art, Karousel did a fantastic job and more thought went into the design than the average reader will initially expect.  More on that latter.

The actual journey that we take with Vinty, whether she is dreaming of stardom or fending off the soul crushing nature of actual reality, is short but sweet.  Clocking at under 20 minutes to explore all of the paths (which function in a Bad End versus a continuation of the story system), Without Within can be immensely charming, funny, sweet, a bit too real at times for those of us that did a stint as a starving artist.  The story is a love letter to creative types but something everyone can relate to: It isn't easy to blaze your own trail but if it was would the journey actually be worth it?

So, is Without Within worth your time?  Absolutely!  It is a cute little tale that is short but full of character.  Is Without Within worth your money?  That is a difficult question to answer and one I leave up to the reader after they finish the story.  If you enjoyed it, as I did, I personally suggest spending the meager amount to show your support and unlock some goodies.  The Art Book in particular is very interesting as they discuss some of the design decisions for the game and you get an interesting inside look at how a small team would go about putting together a project like this.

But if you find Visual Novels even the least bit appealing, there is literally no reason to not spend a bit of time to go through this one.

Score: 7/10
